questions.question: A 10 y/o girl presents with a sore throat, low-grade fever, and swollen neck glands. Examination reveals a thick greyish membrane covering her tonsils. Which among the following is the most suitable culture medium for confirming the diagnosis at the earliest stage?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Loeffler’s serum slope Explanation: Corynebacterium diphtheria colonies can be visualized as early as 6-8 hours in Loeffler’s serum slope Isolation of C.diptheriae Fastidious Aerobe and facultative anaerobe; do not grow on ordinary medium Grows best in an enriched medium such as blood agar, chocolate agar, and Loeffler’s serum slope Isolation in Different Culture Media Culture Media Colony appearance Evaluation Loeffler’s serum slope Small Circular opaque disks Glistening, White with a yellow tinge Advantage: Growth can be detected as early as 6–8 hours. The best medium for metachromatic granule production Disadvantage: Supports the growth of other throat commensals also Potassium tellurite agar (McLeod’s and Hoyle’s-modified PTA) (Options A, C&D ruled out) Grey or black colour Advantage: Throat commensals are inhibited Disadvantage: Colonies appear only after 48 hours of incubation Sheep blood agar Small Circular White Sometimes hemolytic(mitis biotype) Differentiate colonies from streptococcal or staphylococcal pharyngitis, which may simulate diphtheria. The serum slope may show growth in 4-8 hours but, if negative, will have to be incubated for 24 hours Identification by biochemical tests is done by Sugar fermentation test using Hiss’s serum sugar media It is necessary to use Hiss's serum sugars for fermentation tests. Diphtheria ferments glucose, galactose, maltose, and dextrin Produces acid but without gas Do not ferment lactose, mannitol or sucrose. Reference: Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition Page 602 Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 242 Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th edition, Page 981-983

questions.question: A 6 y/o child presents with a sore throat, low-grade fever, and a greyish membrane covering the tonsils. The doctor suspects diphtheria. Which diagnostic test is used for confirming the production of diphtheria toxin by C.diptheriae?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Elek's gel test Explanation: Elek’s gel test is used to demonstrate the diphtheria toxin produced by C.diptheriae. Demonstration of toxicity In-vivo test- subcutaneous and intracutaneous tests done on guinea pigs In vitro test- Test Features Elek’s gel precipitation test gel precipitation test" data-author="" data-hash="9889" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/duP7wodTOR1trhtzKtWV1744446503.png" /> Immunodiffusion in gel. The strain isolated is streaked onto a media containing a filter paper soaked with antitoxin. If the strain is toxigenic, it liberates the toxin which diffuses in the agar and meets with the antitoxin to produce an arrow-shaped precipitation band. Used to know the relatedness between the strains isolated during an outbreak. Schicks test Based on the ability of circulating antitoxin to neutralize the diphtheria toxin given intradermally Indicates immunity or susceptibility to the disease. Tissue culture test The toxigenicity can be demonstrated by incorporating the strains in the agar overlay of cell culture monolayers. The toxin produced diffuses into the cells below and causes lysis of the cells PCR Detection of Toxin gene (tox) has been developed to detect the presence of genes coding for the toxin, in clinical isolates ELISA Detect toxins from the patient's isolate using an antitoxin and enzyme-substrate system. Blood culture (Option A) and throat swab culture (Option B) are used to isolate and identify Corynebacterium diphtheriae, the bacterium that causes diphtheria, but it does not specifically identify volutin granules. Gram stain (Option C) helps identify rod-shaped Corynebacterium diphtheriae but does not help stain the metachromatic granules

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding Nocardia and Actinomyces is false?

options.A: Actinomyces infections are endogenous, whereas Nocardia infections are exogenous.
options.B: Actinomyces is nonacid-fast, while Nocardia is partially acid-fast.
options.C: Penicillin is the preferred treatment for Nocardia infections.
options.D: Nocardia is an obligate aerobe, whereas Actinomyces is anaerobic.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Penicillin is the preferred treatment for Nocardia infections. Explanation: Penicillin is the preferred treatment for Actinomyces, whereas Nocardia is treated with cotrimoxazole. Features Actinomycetes Nocardia Acid-fastness (Option B ruled out) Nonacid-fast Partially acid-fast O2 Requirement (Option D ruled out) Anaerobe Obligate aerobe Habitat (Option A ruled out) Found as oral flora Infections occur endogenously The usual habitat is the soil Infections occur exogenously Risk factors Immunocompetent also Usually only in immunocompromised Clinical forms Cervicofascial, abdominal, and others. Pulmonary, CNS forms, Actinomycetoma Granules Sulfur granules are hard and not emulsifiable, consist of branching filamentous bacilli, and are surrounded by clubs (sun-ray appearance) Granules are soft and lobulated and also show a sun-ray appearance Commonly found in mycetoma, rare in other conditions Culture Spidery molar teeth colony in solid media Fluffy ball at the bottom of the liquid medium Colonies are creamy, wrinkled, and pink Isolation is done in Selective media Paraffin bait technique LJ medium Treatment (Option C) Penicillin Cotrimoxazole Reference: Apurba Sastry, Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 544 Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th edition, Pages 357-360

questions.question: A microbiologist cultivates a sample from a patient suspected of having a Corynebacterium infection. The bacteria grow slowly on standard media but grow well in a medium containing lipids. Which Corynebacterium species is likely being cultured?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) C. urealyticum Explanation: Corynebacterium urealyticum is a lipophilic Corynebacterium species. Group Growth Characteristics Example Species Lipophilic Grow slowly on standard media; enhanced by lipids C. jeikeium C. urealyticum (Option B) Non-lipophilic Grow well on standard laboratory media C. striatum (Option A ruled out) C. amycolatum C. pseudodiphtheriticum C. pseudotuberculosis (Option C ruled out) C. ulcerans (Option D ruled out) C. minutissimum Some Important types of Corynebacteria and their important characteristics: Species Lipophilicity Characteristics C. pseudotuberculosis Non-Lipophilic Infection in cows, transmitted via milk. Erythromycin sensitivity Diphtheria antitoxin is a protective C. minutissimum Non-Lipophilic Erythrasma rash in axilla and groin These lesions demonstrate coral red fluorescence on Wood's lamp evaluation C.jeikeium Lipophilic Infections of the cutaneous and vascular system. High mortality rate Immunocompromised host Multidrug resistance and responds only to vancomycin

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes diphtheria toxin (DT) based on the provided information? production.

options.A: DT, a DNA virus, integrates its tox gene into Corynebacterium diphtheriae, allowing toxin
options.B: The iron concentration in the blood affects DT production.
options.C: DT enters host cells by binding to DNA, which triggers direct cell lysis.
options.D: C.diptheriae spreads throughout the bloodstream, causing both bacteremia and toxaemia.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Iron concentration of blood affects DT production. Explanation: DT production is regulated by the availability of iron; low iron concentrations trigger the expression of the tox gene. High production of DT with low iron availability (0.1 mg/l); iron addition inhibits production (0.5mg/l). Diphtheria Toxin: Aspect Details Production and Structure DT is a protein exotoxin produced by the toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Consists of two fragments(Bipartite), A and B, with a molecular weight of approximately 62,000 daltons. (Option C ruled out) Role of Lysogenic β -phage The tox gene is carried by a lysogenic β -phage. Only phage-infected strains produce toxin; nontoxigenic strains can become toxigenic if infected. Corynebacterium diphtheriae remains localized at the infection site, with only the toxin entering circulation, causing toxaemia but not bacteremia. (Option D ruled out) Mechanism of Action Fragment B binds host cell receptors, facilitating fragment A entry into the cytoplasm. Fragment A catalyses ADP-ribosylation of EF-2, halting protein synthesis. Potency The lethal dose for a 250g guinea pig: is 0.0001 mg. The estimated lethal dose for humans: 130 ng/kg body weight. Systemic Effects DT spreads via blood, causing myocarditis and neuritis. Myocarditis is potentially fatal. Factors Affecting Production Influenced by environmental factors: alkaline pH (7.8-8.0), oxygen, and iron concentration in the growth medium. High production with low iron availability (0.1 mg/l); iron addition inhibits production (0.5 mg/l). Toxoid Formation Treatment with formalin (0.2-0.4%), and incubation at 37°C for 4-6 weeks converts DT to toxoid. Toxoid lacks toxicity but induces an immune response; used in vaccines. Immunity Immunity is primarily mediated by antitoxin antibodies neutralizing DT. DT, a DNA virus, integrates its tox gene into Corynebacterium diphtheriae, allowing toxin production (Option A): Diphtheria toxin (DT) is not a DNA virus. It is a protein exotoxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae when infected by a lysogenic β -phage carrying the tox gene. DT enters host cells by binding to DNA, which triggers direct cell lysis (Option C) :DT does not bind to DNA to enter cells or cause cell lysis directly; instead, Fragment B binds to host cell receptors, facilitating the entry of Fragment A, which inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylation of EF-2. DT primarily causes localized skin lesions, via direct contact with infected individuals (Option D): Diphtheria is primarily transmitted through direct contact or respiratory droplets. Its hallmark symptoms include respiratory distress and a pseudomembrane in the throat , rather than primarily causing localized skin lesions. While cutaneous diphtheria is possible, it's not the main presentation of diphtheria toxin effects.

questions.question: A child presented with a sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes in the neck. Throat culture was subjected to Albert's stain and revealed bacilli arranged in a Chinese letter pattern. The patient's condition deteriorates rapidly, with signs of severe respiratory distress. Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for the clinical manifestations seen in this patient?

options.A: Cleavage of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide by Diphtheria Toxin (DT).
options.B: Inactivation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2) by Exotoxin A.
options.C: Binding of fragment B to human cell receptors by Diphtheria Toxin (DT).
options.D: Secretion of toxins by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Binding of fragment B to human cell receptors by Diphtheria Toxin (DT). revealing bacilli arranged in Chinese letter pattern points to a diagnosis of Diptheria caused by C.diptheriae In diphtheria caused by C. diphtheriae, Diphtheria Toxin (DT) is primarily responsible for the severe clinical manifestations. Fragment B of DT binds to specific receptors on human cells (Option C) → facilitating the entry of fragment A into the cytoplasm (Option B ruled out) → fragment A ADPribosylates elongation factor 2 (EF-2), halting protein synthesis → leading to cell death. This mechanism contributes significantly to the respiratory distress and other severe symptoms observed in diphtheria patients. Cleavage of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide by Diphtheria Toxin (DT) (Option A): The primary toxic action involves the ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2), which results from the toxin's enzymatic activity using NAD as a substrate. Secretion of toxins by Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option D): It refers to a different bacterium and a different set of toxins . Pseudomonas aeruginosa is not the causative agent of diphtheria, and its toxins are not involved in the pathogenesis of this disease. Reference: Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition Page 600 Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th edition, Page 346

questions.question: A patient presents with severe swelling of the neck, along with difficulty swallowing. O/E there was a grey-white pseudomembrane in the throat. Which of the following bacteria is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Corynebacterium diphtheriae Explanation: The patient’s symptoms and clinical findings are suggestive of diphtheria. Primarily caused by toxigenic strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Characterized by the hallmark "bull's neck" presentation due to severe neck swelling from infection and inflammatory response to the diphtheria toxin. Clinical Features Complications Sore throat Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) Low-grade fever Pseudomembrane formation in the throat Non-healing ulcers covered by grey membrane on the skin Myocarditis Neurological complications (e.g., paralysis, neuropathy) Renal failure Airway obstruction Streptococcus pyogenes (Option A) may cause infections resulting in sore throat & fever, but it never presents with a Bull’s neck appearance or a grey-white pseudomembrane. Haemophilus influenza & Neisseria meningitidis (Options C & D) are usually associated with pneumonia and meningitis symptoms and are also not

questions.question: A 7 y/o presents with a sore throat, low-grade fever, and difficulty swallowing. O/E, he has a greyish membrane covering his tonsils and swollen cervical lymph nodes. Which investigation helps to identify the presence of volutin granules in a case of suspected diphtheria?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Albert Stain Explanation: Albert stain of Corynebacterium diphtheria shows bacilli with metachromatic granules. Albert Stain Principle: Albert's stain causes the metachromatic granules of C. diphtheriae to appear bluish-purple upon staining. Corynebacterium diphtheria shows chinese letter/ cuneiform appearance Diphtheroids show regular and palisading appearance with lesser number of granules Type Components Function Albert Solution 1 Malachite Green for organism staining Toluidine Blue for metachromatic staining Enhances contrast and specificity in staining. Albert Solution 2 Iodine Specifically targets volutin or Babes-Ernst granules. Procedure: Stain the smear with Albert I stain, then drain and wash it. Apply Albert II stain to cover the smear, then drain it. Application: Corynebacterium diphtheriae are slender bacilli arranged in V or L shapes, characterized by metachromatic granules (polar bodies, volutin, or Babes-Ernst granules) at the poles of the bacilli. Albert's, Neisser's, and Ponder's stains help stain these distinctive granules in the bacteria. These granules are also Found in Spirillum, Gardnerella, Yersinia pestis, yeast, and Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) A throat swab culture (Option A) is used to isolate and identify Corynebacterium diphtheriae, the bacterium that causes diphtheria, but it does not specifically identify volutin granules. Gram stain (Option B) helps identify rod-shaped Corynebacterium diphtheriae but does not help stain the metachromatic granules Elek’s test (Option C) is used to detect the production of diphtheria toxin by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, confirming the bacterium's pathogenicity

questions.question: A 2-month-old infant is brought in for vaccination. The paediatrician recommends administering the first dose of the DPT vaccine. Which among the following statements is false regarding the DPT vaccine? units

options.A: DPT is given at the anterolateral aspect of the thigh..
options.B: Thiomersal is used as a preservative.
options.C: DPT should be kept at 2-8 Celsius.
options.D: The pediatric dose of diphtheria toxoid contains 2 Lf units, whereas the adult dose contains 25 Lf

questions.explanation: dose contains 25 Lf units Correct Answer: D) The pediatric dose of diphtheria toxoid contains 2 Lf units, whereas the adult dose contains 25 Lf units. Explanation: The pediatric dose of diphtheria toxoid contains 25Lf units, whereas the adult dose contains 2Lf units. Types of vaccine Single vaccine: Diphtheria toxoid (DT) is prepared by incubating the toxin with formalin and then adsorbed onto alum. Alum acts as an adjuvant and increases the immunogenicity of toxoid. Combined vaccine: Type Composition DPT Dt (Diphtheria Toxoid) Pertussis whole cell TT (Tetanus toxoid) The pertussis component acts as an adjuvant and increases the immunogenicity of DT & TT DaPT DT TT Acellular pertussis(aP) Td Tetanus toxoid Adult dose 2Lf of diphtheria toxin Pentavalent DPT Haemophilus influenza B Hepatitis B Schedule Children 7 doses are given- 3 doses of pentavalent vaccine at 6, 10, and 14 weeks of birth + 2 booster doses of DPT at 16–24 months and 5 years + another 2 booster doses of Td at 10 years and 16 years Pregnant women 2 doses of Td at 1 month interval Adults >18 years -completed primary vaccination >18 years completed primary vaccination Td booster dose is indicated every 10 years till 65 years. 3 doses of Td given at 0, 1 month, and 1 year Site: DPT is given deep intramuscularly (IM) at the anterolateral aspect of the thigh (Option A ruled out) Preservative: Thiomersal (0.01%) is used (Option B ruled out) Storage : DPT should be kept at 2–8C (Option C ruled out) Dose : The usual pediatric dose of diphtheria toxoid contains 25 Lf units, whereas the adult dose contains 2 Lf units Adverse Reaction : Fever: Common, occurring in nearly 50% of cases. Neurotoxic Reactions: Inconsolable crying lasting more than 3 hours. Hypotonic-hyporesponsive episode (HHE). Febrile seizures and encephalopathy. Contraindications: Avoid in progressive neurological conditions (e.g., active epilepsy) but permissible in non-progressive conditions (e.g., cerebral palsy). Reference: Brock Biology of Microorganisms, 15th edition, Page 893 Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition Page 604 Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 245 HHE , Pertusis . Fever , Contraindications

questions.question: A 7-year-old child presents with severe throat pain, difficulty swallowing, and a thick grey membrane extending to the nasopharynx. Given these clinical features, what would be the initial dose of diphtheria antitoxin to administer?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 40000-60000 Explanation: 40000-60000 units of diphtheria antitoxin are administered if the disease extends up to the nasopharynx Treatment Passive immunity with Antidiphtheric serum- ADS (antitoxin) is the treatment of choice as it neutralizes the toxin A test dose is given to check hypersensitivity It is given IV or IM depending upon the stage of illness: Type of Disease Antitoxin Early stage <48hrs 20,000-40,000 IM or IV Nasopharyngeal Disease 40,000-60,000 IM or IV Extensive disease with neck disease (bull neck) > 3 days 80,000-120,000 half IM or half IV Antibiotics: Penicillin or Erythromycin is the drug of choice Useful only if given early disease (<6hrs)-before the toxin is released. Prevents further release of toxins by killing bacteria Treatment of carriers and for cutaneous diphtheria

questions.question: Match the type of diphtheria bacilli biotypes with their characteristic colonies on Tellurite Blood Agar. 1) Gravis a) Poached egg 2) Intermedius b) Daisy's head 3) Mitis
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a Explanation: Corynebacterium produces characteristic colonies on Tellurite Blood Agar differentiating into 3 biotypes, namely C. gravis - Daisy head colonies C. intermedius - Frog’s egg colonies C. mitis - Poached egg colonies Aspect Gravis Intermedius Mitis Morphology -Usually short rods, with uniform staining, few or no granules. -Some degree of pleomorphism, with irregularly barred, snow-shoe and tear-drop forms Long barred forms with clubbed ends; poor granulation, very pleomorphic Long, curved, pleomorphic rods with prominent granulation Colony on tellurite blood agar -In 18 hours, the colony is 1-2 mm in size, with a greyish-black centre, paler, semitranslucent periphery and commencing crenation of edge. -In 2-3 days, 3-5 mm in size, flat colony with raised dark centre and crenated edge with radial striation— ‘daisy head’ colony -18-hour colony, small, 1 mm in size, misty. -Does not enlarge in 48 hours, smoother, more glistening periphery and a lighter ring near the edge— ‘frog’s egg’ colony -Size variable, shiny black. -In 2-3 days, colonies become flat, with a central elevation— ‘poached egg’ colony Consistency of colonies Like ‘cold margarine’, brittle, moves as a whole on the plate, not easily picked out or emulsifiable Intermediate between gravis and mitis Soft, buttery, easily emulsifiable Hemolysis Variable Non-hemolytic Usually hemolytic Growth in broth Surface pellicle, granular deposit, little or no turbidity Turbidity in 24 hours, clearing in 48 hours, with fine granular sediment Diffuse turbidity with soft pellicle later Glycogen and starch fermentation Positive Negative Negative Reference: Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition Page 243 Biotypes of Corynebacterium Diphtheriae

questions.question: Which of the following clinical forms of actinomycosis best describes the two given statements? Statement 1- The most common clinical form of actinomycosis Statement 2- Abscesses in bone and soft tissue, with chronic draining sinuses to the exterior
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1)- Cervicofacial, 2)- Pelvic Explanation: The cervicofacial form is the most common type, usually presenting as a painless, slow-growing hard mass with cutaneous fistulas, commonly known as a lumpy jaw or woody jaw. The pelvic form is often associated with the use of intrauterine devices, producing abscesses in bone and soft tissue, with chronic draining sinuses to the exterior. Clinical Form Description Cervicofacial The most common form- usually presents as a painless, slow-growing hard mass with cutaneous fistulas, commonly known as a lumpy jaw . Indurated lesions on the cheek and submaxillary regions. Thoracic Lesions in the lung that may involve the pleura and pericardium, spreading outwards through the chest wall Abdominal Lesions usually around the cecum involving neighbouring tissues and the abdominal wall. Infection can spread to the liver via the portal vein. Pelvic Often associated with the use of intrauterine devices, producing abscesses in bone and soft tissue, with chronic draining sinuses to the exterior.

questions.question: Which statement about clinical manifestations of Listeria monocytogenes infection is False?

options.A: Pregnant women infected with Listeria monocytogenes may experience flu-like symptoms.
options.B: Neonatal listeriosis can present as early-onset or late-onset disease.
options.C: Listeria monocytogenes infection in adults very rarely leads to meningitis.
options.D: Immunocompromised individuals are at higher risk of severe Listeria monocytogenes infections.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Listeria monocytogenes infection in adults rarely leads to meningitis. or those who are immunocompromised. Listeria monocytogenes Mode of Transmission Contaminated food Vertical transmission (mother to fetus, during birth) Common Food Sources Contaminated coleslaw Milk, Soft cheeses "Ready-to-eat" foods (delicatessen meat, uncooked hotdogs) Age Groups at Risk Neonates Elderly individuals Increased Risk Factors Use of proton pump inhibitors Pregnant women Immunocompromised individuals Survival in Food Survives refrigeration (4°C) Found in stored foods (aged soft cheeses, packaged meats, milk, cold salads) Infection Type Sporadic Outbreaks can occur Psychrotrophic L. monocytogenes is a psychrotrophic organism with an optimum growth temperature of 30ºC to 37ºC but has the ability to grow at a wide range of temperatures from 1ºC to 45ºC. Motility Shows Tumbling and Differential motility(motile at 25.C by forming actin rockets, non motile at 37.C) Pathogenesis Intracellular survival: lysis of phagosome (listeriolysin O) Host cell actin polymerization (cell membrane approach) Direct cell-to-cell spread (listeriopods) Clinical Manifestations Neonatal listeriosis: Early-onset and late-onset disease (Option B ruled out) Pregnant women: Granulomatosis infantiseptica in baby in 3rd trimester Fetal complications (abortion, preterm delivery) Maternal complications (flu-like symptoms, bacteremia, rarely meningitis) (Option A ruled out) Adults: Bacteremia and meningitis (elderly, >60 years) Immunosuppression- higher risk (steroid therapy, HIV, diabetes, malignancy) (Option D ruled out) Post-kidney transplant meningitis (1-month post-transplant) Gastroenteritis (consumption of contaminated milk, meat, salads) Reference: Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition Page 699 Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page 351,352 Granulomatous Motility , Psychrotrophic

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding laboratory diagnosis and characteristics of Listeria monocytogenes is false?

options.A: Shows the tumbling type of motility at 37°C.
options.B: Growth on PALCAM agar is enhanced by the presence of antibiotics.
options.C: The cold enrichment technique involves storing clinical materials at 4°C.
options.D: Experimental inoculation in rabbits causes marked monocytosis.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Shows the tumbling type of motility at 37°C. Explanation: Listeria shows tumbling type of motility at 25°C and non-motile at 37°C, which is known as differential motility. Laboratory Diagnosis of Listeria monocytogenes: Motility: Shows tumbling type of motility at 25°C. Spreads from cell to cell by forming actin rockets Nonmotile at 37°C, which is known as differential motility. Temperature-dependent flagella expression controls this differential motility. Culture: Grows on blood agar, producing β -hemolytic colonies. Grows well on chocolate agar, which supports its growth. Selective media - PALCAM agar , containing a mixture of antibiotics. (Option B ruled out) Isolation: Isolation from - cervical and vaginal secretions, lochia (postpartum discharge), meconium (infant's first stool), cord blood, blood, and cerebrospinal fluid. Incubation is done under a 5% CO2 environment on blood agar. The cold enrichment technique - effective method for isolation. It involves storing materials in tryptose phosphate or thioglycollate broth at 4°C. (Option C ruled out) Subcultures are performed at weekly intervals for 1-6 months to enhance isolation. Identification: Identification is primarily through biochemical tests- catalase positive. Antibody detection against listeriolysin O can aid in diagnosis. cAMP positive Experimental Inoculation in Rabbits causes marked Monocytosis which is also observed in human listeriosis. (Option D ruled out) Anton Test: Instillation into the eyes of rabbits produces keratoconjunctivitis. Sereny's test done for enteroinvasive E coli and to check for invasiveness in Listeria Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 402, 403 Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 694 Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th edition, Pages 352-354 Sereny test , CAMP Motility
